question: It is true that an Expression Tree is a type of binary tree used to evaluate mathematical expressions.
It is false that an Expression Tree always has numbers in its internal nodes.
It is true that in an Expression Tree, operators are stored in leaf nodes.
It is false that the root of an Expression Tree always represents an operand.
It is true that postorder traversal is commonly used to evaluate an Expression Tree.
It is false that inorder traversal is used to directly compute the result of an Expression Tree.
It is true that the expression (5 + 3) * (8 - 2) will have '*' as the root node in its Expression Tree.
It is false that every Binary Tree is an Expression Tree.
It is true that a Heap is always a complete binary tree.
It is false that a Heap can have more than two children per node.
It is true that a Max Heap always has the largest element at the root.
It is false that a Min Heap stores its largest element at the root.
It is true that in a Max Heap, each parent node has a value greater than or equal to its children.
It is false that in a Min Heap, each parent node has a value greater than its children.
It is true that Heap insertion follows the heapify-up process to maintain order.
It is false that Heap deletion does not require heapify-down to maintain the heap structure.
It is true that a Heap is an example of a priority queue.
It is false that a Min Heap allows quick access to the largest element.
It is true that Expression Trees and Heaps are both based on binary trees but serve different purposes.
It is false that Expression Trees are used for sorting elements.
